questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a severe respiratory infection. The physician explains the body's immune response, detailing the roles of different immune systems in fighting infections. Which of the following statements about innate and acquired immunity, as explained by the physician, is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Innate immunity provides a rapid response to infection without prior exposure to the antigen.

options.label: B
options.text: Acquired immunity develops over time and requires prior exposure to the antigen.

options.label: C
options.text: Innate immunity has immunological memory and can recognize specific antigens.

options.label: D
options.text: Acquired immunity involves T cells and B cells, which are specific to particular pathogens.

questions.correct_answer: C. Innate immunity has immunological memory and can recognize specific antigens.
questions.explanation:
Innate Immunity

Acquired/Adaptive Immunity

Inherent resistance to infection from birth

Resistance to infection developed over a lifetime

Rapid immune response, occurring in minutes

Immune response takes days to develop

No prior exposure to the antigen needed (Option A ruled out)

Requires prior exposure to the antigen (Option B ruled out)

Limited diversity, operates within a restricted set of reactions

More diverse and specialized in responses

Lacks immunological memory

Immunological memory is present

Recognizes microbial antigens shared by many microbes (pathogen-associated molecular patterns)

Recognizes antigens specific to each microbe

Host cell receptors are non-specific (e.g., Toll-like receptors)

Host cell receptors are specific (e.g., T and B cell receptors) (Option D ruled out)

Components of Innate Immunity

  • Physical barriers such as skin and mucosa
  • Physiological barriers (e.g., body temperature)
  • Phagocytic cells (e.g., neutrophils)
  • Natural killer (NK) cells
  • Other lymphocyte subsets (γδ T cells, NK-T cells)
  • Marginal-zone and B-1 B cells
  • Mast cells, macrophages, dendritic cells
  • Complement pathways (alternative and mannose-binding)
  • Fever and inflammation responses
  • Normal flora
  • Cytokines: TNF-α, various interleukins, IFN-α, β, and TGF-β
  • Acute phase reactant proteins (APRs)

Components of Acquired Immunity

  • T cells
  • B cells
  • Classical complement pathway
  • Cytokines (e.g., IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IFN-γ)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic after experiencing frequent infections. The physician explains the roles of various lymphoid organs in his immune system. Which of the following statements about primary and secondary lymphoid organs is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: The thymus is responsible for the maturation of T cells.

options.label: B
options.text: The spleen filters blood-borne antigens and activates T and B cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Bone marrow is the primary site for B cell maturation.

options.label: D
options.text: Lymph nodes are primarily involved in hematopoiesis.

questions.correct_answer: D. Lymph nodes are primarily involved in hematopoiesis.
questions.explanation:
Primary Lymphoid Organs

Secondary Lymphoid Organs

Bone Marrow:

  • Origin of all blood cells from pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells (process called hematopoiesis).
  • Hematopoiesis shifts to bone marrow from liver after fetal life, eventually confined to axial bones after puberty.
  • Progenitor T and B cells develop in bone marrow; B cells mature here, while T cell progenitors migrate to the thymus. (Option C ruled out)

Lymph Nodes:

  • Filter antigens and activate T and B cells.
  • Structured into cortex (B cell area), paracortex (T cell area), and medulla (rich in plasma cells).

Spleen:

  • Largest secondary lymphoid organ, involved in filtering blood-borne antigens. (Option B ruled out)
  • Contains white pulp (T and B cells) and red pulp (site of RBC destruction).

Thymus:

  • Site of T cell proliferation and maturation. (Option A ruled out)
  • Developed from the third/fourth pharyngeal pouch in embryonic life.
  • Active during childhood, decreases in size after puberty.
  • Thymic hormones (e.g., thymulin, thymopoietin) help attract and mature T cells.
  • Central tolerance occurs here, removing self-reactive T cells to prevent autoimmunity.

Mucosa-associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT):

  • Located in mucosal sites (intestine, respiratory, urogenital tracts) to protect against pathogens.
  • Includes loose clusters of lymphoid cells and organized structures (e.g., tonsils, Peyer’s patches in intestines).

questions.text: During T cell development in the thymus, immature T cells undergo a selection process. Which of the following statements correctly describes this selection process?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive selection allows survival of T cells that cannot recognize MHC molecules

options.label: B
options.text: Negative selection eliminates T cells that react with self-antigens

options.label: C
options.text: Both CD4 and CD8 markers are retained on mature T cells

options.label: D
options.text: Double-negative T cells directly transform into single-positive T cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Negative selection eliminates T cells that react with self-antigens
questions.explanation:
T-Lymphocytes

T Cell Development Stages

1. Double Negative Stage (CD4- CD8-)

• Express CD3 molecule

• 95% express TCR αβ

• 5% express TCR γδ

 

2. Double Positive Stage (CD4+ CD8+)

• Undergo positive selection (5% survive)

• Undergo negative selection (2-5% eliminated)

 

3. Single Positive Stage

• Either CD4+ or CD8+ T cells

• Released into circulation

Major T Cell Types

1. Helper T Cells (CD4+)

• TH1: Secrete IL-2, IFN-γ, TNF-β

• TH2: Secrete IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-10, IL-13

• TH17: Produces IL-17, IL-22

 

2. Cytotoxic T Cells (CD8+)

• Kill virus-infected cells and tumor cells

 

3. Regulatory T Cells

• Express CD4, CD25, Foxp3 - Causes IPEX syndrome( Immune dysregulation , Polyendocrinopathy , Enteropathy, X linked disorder.

• Suppress immune response

Key Surface Markers

• CD3: Universal T cell marker

• TCR: Antigen recognition

• CD4: Helper T cells, MHC-II restricted

• CD8: Cytotoxic T cells, MHC-I restricted

• Memory markers: CD45RO (memory), CD45RA (naive)

Functions

• Helper T cells: Coordinate immune response

• Cytotoxic T cells: Direct cell killing

• Regulatory T cells: Maintain self-tolerance

• Memory T cells: Long-term immunity

questions.text: A research student is studying cytokine profiles of different T helper cell subsets. In the experiment, naive CD4+ T cells were activated and differentiated into different subsets. Which of the following correctly matches the T helper cell subset with its primary cytokine secretion pattern and major function? a. TH-1 1. IL-17, IL-22 x. Recruit neutrophils b. TH-2 2. IFN-γ, TNF-β y. Promote antibody production c. TH-17 3. IL-4, IL-5, IL-10 z. Enhance macrophage activation
questions.explanation:
T Helper Subset

Key Cytokines

Major Functions

Role in Immunity

TH1 Cells

• IL-2

• IFN-γ

• TNF-β

• Activate macrophages

• Enhance cell-mediated immunity

• Stimulate cytotoxic T cells

• Protection against intracellular pathogens

• Mediate delayed-type hypersensitivity

TH2 Cells

• IL-4

• IL-5

• IL-6

• IL-10

• IL-13

• Promote B cell proliferation

• Enhance antibody production

• Stimulate IgE class switching

• Promote eosinophil growth

• Protection against extracellular pathogens

• Mediate allergic responses

• Involved in helminth immunity

TH17 Cells

• IL-17

• IL-22

• Recruit neutrophils

• Enhance inflammation

• Promote tissue inflammation

• Protection at mucosal surfaces

• Involved in autoimmune diseases

• Contribute to inflammatory conditions

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism by which CD8+ T cells eliminate virus-infected target cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Secretion of antibodies that neutralize viral particles

options.label: B
options.text: Release of perforins and granzymes leading to target cell apoptosis

options.label: C
options.text: Production of IL-4 and IL-5 to enhance eosinophil recruitment

options.label: D
options.text: Activation of complement cascade to lyse infected cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Release of perforins and granzymes leading to target cell apoptosis
questions.explanation:
CD8+ T cells (cytotoxic T cells)

CD8+ T-Cell Activation

1. Antigen-specific signal:

• TCR binds to peptide-MHC I complex

• CD8 interacts with α3 domain of MHC-I

 

2. Costimulatory signal:

• CD28 binds to B7 on target cells

 

3. Cytokine signal:

• IL-2 (from TH1 cells)

Mechanism of Action

1. Recognition Phase:

• Binds to virus-infected or tumor cells

• Recognizes antigenic peptides with MHC-I

 

2. Killing Phase:

• Releases perforins (form pores)

• Releases granzymes (enter through pores)

• Induces apoptosis through caspase pathway

 

3. Resolution Phase:

• Detachment from target cell

• Can kill multiple target cells sequentially

Types

1. Naive CD8+ T cells:

• Circulating, unexposed to antigen

 

2. Effector CD8+ T cells:

• Activated, cytotoxic function

 

3. Memory CD8+ T cells:

• Long-lived

• Rapid response to re-exposure

Primary Functions

• Elimination of virus-infected cells

• Destruction of tumor cells

• Defense against intracellular pathogens

• Generation of immunological memory

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct sequence of events in B cell-T cell interaction leading to antibody production?

options.label: A
options.text: B cells undergo class switching after CD40-CD40L interaction without requiring cytokine signals

options.label: B
options.text: T cells present antigens to B cells via MHC-II molecules

options.label: C
options.text: B cells process antigen, present via MHC-II to T cells, receive CD40L and cytokine signals

options.label: D
options.text: CD28-B7 interaction between B and T cells is sufficient for plasma cell differentiation

questions.correct_answer: C. B cells process antigen, present via MHC-II to T cells, receive CD40L and cytokine signals
questions.explanation:
Stage

Process

Key Components

Initial B Cell Activation

1. Antigen Recognition:

• B cell captures antigen via surface IgM/IgD

• Antigen internalization

 

2. Antigen Processing:

• Processed into peptides

• Loaded onto MHC-II molecules

• B cell receptor (BCR) (IgM and IgD)

• Surface immunoglobulins

• MHC-II molecules

B Cell-T Cell Interaction

1. Signal Generation:

• Signal 1: Antigen presentation to TH cells

• Signal 2: CD40-CD40L interaction

• Signal 3: Cytokine stimulation

 

2. T Cell Help:

• TH1: IFN-γ (IgG production)

• TH2: IL-4 (IgE production)

• TCR-MHC-II complex

• CD40-CD40L

• Cytokine receptors

• Co-stimulatory molecules

B Cell Response

1. Germinal Center Formation:

• B cell proliferation

• Somatic hypermutation

• Class switching

 

2. Differentiation:

• Into plasma cells

• Into memory B cells

• Antibody production

• Affinity maturation

• Immunological memory

Outcomes

1. Immediate Response:

• Antibody secretion

• Different Ig classes based on cytokines

 

2. Long-term Response:

• Memory formation

• Enhanced secondary response

• IgG, IgA, IgE production

• High-affinity antibodies

• Long-lived plasma cells

• Memory B cells

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines and mechanisms are correctly associated with this isotype switch?

options.label: A
options.text: IFN-γ stimulation leading to direct IgM to IgE switch

options.label: B
options.text: IL-4 and CD40-CD40L interaction leading to IgE production

options.label: C
options.text: IL-2 stimulation alone causes isotype switching

options.label: D
options.text: TGF-β inducing direct IgE production without prior IgM synthesis

questions.correct_answer: B. IL-4 and CD40-CD40L interaction leading to IgE production
questions.explanation:
Process

Key Features

Requirements

Initial Antibody Synthesis

• First antibody produced is IgM

• Later co-expression of IgD

• Occurs in bone marrow

• No T cell help needed

• Gene rearrangement

• VDJ recombination

• Expression of RAG genes

Class Switch Requirements

• Occurs in germinal centers

• Requires T-cell help

• Involves DNA recombination

• Irreversible process

• CD40-CD40L interaction

• Specific cytokines

• AID enzyme activity

• Switch recombination

Cytokine Control of Class Switching

• IFN-γ → IgG2a, IgG3

• IL-4 → IgE, IgG4

• TGF-β + IL-5 → IgA

• IL-2,4,5 → IgM

• IL-4,5,6 + IFN-γ → IgG

• TH1 cells (IFN-γ)

• TH2 cells (IL-4)

• Specific transcription factors

• CD40-CD40L required for all switches

Outcomes

• Changed effector functions

• Same antigen specificity

• Different tissue distribution

• Different half-lives

• New constant region

• Same variable region

• Different Fc receptors

• Different complement activation

questions.text: A laboratory analysis reveals an increase in B cells with the expression of CD19 and CD20. Which of the following best describes the role of these B cells?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce antibodies in response to T-cell activation.

options.label: B
options.text: They directly kill infected cells.

options.label: C
options.text: They are involved in cell-mediated immunity.

options.label: D
options.text: They secrete cytokines to modulate the immune response.

questions.correct_answer: A. They produce antibodies in response to T-cell activation.
questions.explanation:
CD19

Present throughout B cell development and maturity; used as a universal B cell marker.

CD20

Expressed from the late pro-B cell stage onward; target for certain therapeutic antibodies.

CD21

Complement receptor involved in B cell activation by enhancing BCR signaling.

CD40

It is critical for interactions with T cells, enables antibody class switching for adaptive immune responses, and is also responsible for Anergy and self-tolerance.

Immunoglobulin Markers: IgM and IgD

Primary B cell receptors on mature, naive B cells.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, blurred vision, and drooping eyelids. Blood tests reveal antibodies against acetylcholine receptors, suggesting myasthenia gravis. The physician explains that the patient's immune system may be reacting to "self" proteins. Which of the following statements best explains the immunological basis for this autoimmune reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: The antigen is presented by MHC Class I molecules to CD8+ T-cells, leading to cytotoxic T-cell-mediated destruction.

options.label: B
options.text: The antigen is presented by MHC Class II molecules to CD4+ T-cells, stimulating an immune response involving helper T-cells and autoantibody production.

options.label: C
options.text: MHC Class I molecules are found only on professional antigen-presenting cells, which present the antigen to helper T-cells.

options.label: D
options.text: MHC Class II molecules are present on all nucleated cells and help in presenting intracellular antigens.

questions.correct_answer: B. The antigen is presented by MHC Class II molecules to CD4+ T-cells, stimulating an immune response involving helper T-cells and autoantibody production.
questions.explanation:
Feature

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expression

Found on almost all nucleated cells

Found mainly on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as macrophages, dendritic cells, and B-cells

Antigen Source

Presents intracellular antigens (e.g., viral or tumor proteins)

Presents extracellular antigens (e.g., bacterial peptides)

Interacts With

CD8+ T-cells (cytotoxic T-cells)

CD4+ T-cells (helper T-cells)

Main HLA Genes

HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C

HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, HLA-DR

Structure

Consists of one α (heavy) chain and β2-microglobulin;

peptide-binding groove formed by α1 and α2

Consists of α and β chains; peptide-binding groove formed by α1 and β1 domains

Function

Identifies and helps eliminate infected or malignant cells by presenting endogenous antigens to CD8+ T-cells

Activates immune response by presenting exogenous antigens to CD4+ T-cells

Peptide Length

Presents shorter peptides (8-10 amino acids)

Presents longer peptides (10-30 amino acids)
